channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Nigeria Is Freeing Children From Boko Haram, Then Locking Them Up
item.media:description: Displaced people taking shelter from the rain at a camp in Maiduguri, Nigeria, in June.
item.media:credit: Jane Hahn for The New York Times
item.description: Civilians, and even infants, are ending up in military detention centers as Nigeria holds people it suspects of being sympathizers of the Islamist extremist group.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: Poor Sanitation Persisted at U.N. Missions Long After Haiti Cholera Crisis
item.media:description: A man bathing in the Meye River in Meye, Haiti, in 2012. Studies have traced the 2010 cholera outbreak there to infected United Nations peacekeepers whose fecal waste had leaked into the river.
item.media:credit: Damon Winter/The New York Times
item.description: Years after the 2010 cholera outbreak in Haiti, auditors found unaddressed public health lapses at the United Nations’ peacekeeping mission there and at other missions.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: U.S. Concedes $400 Million Payment to Iran Was Delayed as Prisoner ‘Leverage’
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry with John Kirby, the department’s spokesman, in October.
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Carlo Allegri
item.description: The State Department said the payment was to settle an old dispute and did not amount to a “ransom” for the release of three American prisoners.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Russian Cruise Missiles Target Syria
item.description: Russian warships in the Mediterranean Sea fired cruise missiles at targets near Aleppo on Friday, a further sign of Moscow's broadening military effort in Syria.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Ryan Lochte Apologizes ‘For My Behavior’ After Rio Robbery Claim
item.media:description: Reporters at the men’s bathroom at a gas station in Rio de Janeiro where four American Olympic swimmers were captured on security video on Aug. 18.
item.media:credit: Mario Tama/Getty Images
item.description: Mr. Lochte issued a statement on Instagram saying he should have been “more careful” when giving a disputed account of an armed robbery.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: U.S. Swimmers’ Disputed Robbery Claim Fuels Tension in Brazil
item.description: Ryan Lochte was accused of fabricating his account of the episode, in which he said armed men had held up him and three teammates. A police chief said they had vandalized a gas station.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: The Interpreter: France’s ‘Burkini’ Bans Are About More Than Religion or Clothing
item.media:description: A woman wearing a “burkini,” a full-body swimsuit designed for Muslims, at a Morocco beach.
item.media:credit: Fadel Senna/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The bans on full-body swimsuits are not primarily about protecting Muslim women from patriarchy, but about shielding France’s non-Muslims from a changing world.
item.dc:creator: AMANDA TAUB

item.title: Germany Proposes Partial Ban on Face Veils in Public Places
item.media:description: There are no official statistics in Germany on the number of women who wear the burqa, which covers the face and body, or the niqab, which covers the hair and face, except for a narrow slit for the eyes. Neither form of attire is seen much on German streets.
item.media:credit: Boris Roesseler/European Pressphoto Agency
item.description: The interior minister said that Muslim women should not wear coverings in schools and colleges, or while driving, appearing before courts or going through passport control.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: An Aging Boy Band Calls It Quits, but Japan Can’t Let Go
item.media:description: The Japanese band SMAP performing with the actress Chiling Lin in Beijing in 2011. The group announced this month that it would be disbanding after decades in the spotlight.
item.media:credit: Li Xueshi/Associated Press
item.description: The nation is awash with anguish over the announcement of a breakup by SMAP, whose youngest member is now pushing 40.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: The Saturday Profile: A Happy Warrior in a Faltering Battle for Indonesian Gay Rights
item.media:description: Dede Oetomo is widely considered the godfather of Indonesia’s gay rights movement.
item.media:credit: Iqro Rinaldi/Reuters
item.description: Dede Oetomo, considered the godfather of Indonesia’s gay rights movement, is fighting a backlash that has turned a long-chilly climate outright hostile.
item.dc:creator: JON EMONT
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Sinosphere: Chinese Claim That World Accepts Its Organ Transplant System Is Rebutted
item.media:description: Dr. Philip J. O’Connell, president of the Transplantation Society, said he had told Chinese presenters at a conference that their country’s decades-long practice of using the organs of executed prisoners had horrified the rest of the world.
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.description: The head of the Transplantation Society said that the decades-long practice of using the organs of executed prisoners, which China says has stopped, had horrified the rest of the world.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Chilling Tale in Duterte’s Drug War: Father and Son Killed in Police Custody
item.media:description: An investigator near the body of a person accused of dealing drugs in the Novaliches area of greater Manila on Wednesday. Since President Rodrigo Duterte took office, he has pledged to carry out an uncompromising crackdown on crime, including drug suspects.
item.media:credit: Jes Aznar for The New York Times
item.description: Even amid the slaughter of the Filipino president’s war on drugs, the killings of Renato and Jaypee Bertes stand out.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Sinosphere: Hong Kong Objects to Alien Presence in Its Skyline (No, Not the Spaceship)
item.description: A poster for the movie “Arrival” depicts an otherworldly craft above Hong Kong’s harbor, but it’s the tower in the foreground that’s really out of place.
item.dc:creator: ALAN WONG

item.title: U.S. Court Upholds United Nations’ Immunity in Cholera Suit
item.description: Despite the United Nations’ admission that it had played a role in an outbreak in Haiti, the decision by a three-judge panel precludes the organization from being sued.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN M. KATZ

item.title: Mexican Federal Police Executed 22 People in Raid, Rights Group Says
item.description: A commission found serious rights violations by security forces in a 2015 raid on a gang-occupied ranch in which 42 civilians and one officer died.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Ukraine Releases More Details on Payments for Trump Aide
item.media:description: Paul Manafort, center, chairman of Donald J. Trump’s presidential campaign, at the Republican National Convention in Cleveland last month.
item.media:credit: Sam Hodgson for The New York Times
item.description: The revelations also point to an outsize role for a former senior member of a pro-Russian party in directing money to Republican and Democratic lobbyists.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER and BARRY MEIER

item.title: Italian Banks Continue to Lend to Stagnant Companies as Debt Pile Mounts
item.media:description: The office of Intesa Sanpaolo in Turin, Italy. Last year, the book seller Feltrinelli was able to secure a 50 million euro line of credit from a syndicate that included Intesa Sanpaolo.
item.media:credit: Marco Bertorello/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Italy accounts for a third of the eurozone’s nonperforming loans. But that hasn’t stopped its banks from extending credit to loss-making companies.
item.dc:creator: LANDON THOMAS Jr.
item.category: Center for Economic and Policy Research
Monte dei Paschi di Siena SpA

item.title: Far-Right Party Trades on Merkel’s Refugee Policies in Her Home State
item.media:description: A pedestrian bridge that connects Gross Klein, a suburb of Rostock, Germany, that has become a focal point in state elections after clashes between local youths and refugees from Afghanistan, Somalia and Syria.
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: Physical clashes involving young refugees have become a focal point in state elections, and a test of the chancellor’s push for integration.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Lower Medal Count in Rio Rattles China’s Olympics Obsession
item.media:description: Xu Jiayu of China after winning silver in the men’s 100-meter backstroke. China is vying to come in second in the gold medal tally in Rio de Janeiro.
item.media:credit: David Gray/Reuters
item.description: The count has long been long viewed as a measure of China’s rising global power, and an uneven showing in the Rio Games has smarted.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Doctors Without Borders Is Pulling Staff After Hospital Bombings in Yemen
item.media:description: Abs Hospital in Hajjah Province was bombed on Monday, killing 19 people. Doctors Without Borders is evacuating staff from it and five other hospitals in northern Yemen because of the bombings.
item.media:credit: Abduljabbar Zeyad/Reuters
item.description: The aid group said it was leaving six hospitals because the Saudi-led military coalition could not provide assurances they would not be bombed again.
item.dc:creator: SHUAIB ALMOSAWA and ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Volkswagen Supplier Played Key Role in Cheating, Court Papers Say
item.media:description: Lawsuits contend that Bosch played a central role in development of a defeat device for Volkswagen’s Audi division in the late 1990s.
item.media:credit: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg
item.description: The automaker could not have modified engine software to deceive emissions regulators without help from Robert Bosch GmbH, lawyers said in a court filing.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING

item.title: Letter From Europe: The Tribal Thrill of the Olympics
item.media:description: Andy Murray of Great Britain won the gold medal in Rio when he beat Juan Martín del Potro of Argentina in the men’s singles in tennis. It was his second straight gold.
item.media:credit: Clive Brunskill/Getty Images
item.description: For Britons and others, the Games offer a vicarious sense of individual accomplishment, and the affirmation of a nation’s niche in a globalized world.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL

item.title: Istalif Journal: War and Pillaging Couldn’t Break an Afghan Village, but a Tumbling Economy May
item.media:description: Potters and vendors on the main street of Istalif, Afghanistan, in June.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: Istalif’s resurgence after the fall of the Taliban in 2001 hardened the reputation for resilience it earned over centuries, but now it is threatened again.
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: How Omran Daqneesh, 5, Became a Symbol of Aleppo’s Suffering
item.description: Images of the dazed and injured child have quickly made him an emblem of the harrowing misery of Syria’s five-year-old civil war.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD

item.title: South Sudan’s Opposition Leader Flees Country as Peace Deal Unravels
item.media:description: The opposition leader Riek Machar in Jonglei State, South Sudan, in 2014.
item.media:credit: Goran Tomasevic/Reuters
item.description: Riek Machar was being targeted by government troops, his spokesmen said, and will soon travel to Ethiopia and try to rebuild support from there.
item.dc:creator: JACEY FORTIN

item.title: 2 Officials in Vietnam Are Killed in Rare Shooting
item.media:description: Prime Minister Nguyen Xuan Phuc of Vietnam, second from left, with a shooting victim in the northern province of Yen Bai on Thursday.
item.media:credit: Vietnam News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: A province’s Communist party secretary and the chairman of a lawmaking body were shot dead in their offices by a forest ranger, who later shot himself. The motive was unknown.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: Sinosphere: Choice of Hong Kong for Organ Transplant Meeting Is Defended
item.media:description: Fang Hui, 28, showing the scar from a living donor organ transplant operation in which she received a portion of her sister’s liver. China is trying to encourage voluntary donations to replace its longstanding reliance on organs from executed prisoners.
item.media:credit: Ng Han Guan/Associated Press
item.description: Organizers said the move did not signify international acceptance of China’s transplant system, which long relied on organs from executed prisoners.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Thomas Cholmondeley, Scion Implicated in Killings of 2 Kenyans, Dies at 48
item.media:description: Thomas Cholmondeley, second from right, during his sentencing in Nairobi, Kenya, in 2009.
item.media:credit: Roberto Schmidt/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: A descendant of British settlers, Mr. Cholmondeley was known as an eccentric outdoorsman who liked fast horses, speedy bikes and guns. He had been hospitalized for hip-replacement surgery.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: Nazi Gold Train May Not Exist, but That Doesn’t Stop Diggers
item.media:description: Police and railway security officials patrolled the closed area where a search is underway for a Nazi train in Walbrzych, Poland.
item.media:credit: Mikolaj Nowacki for The New York Times
item.description: A group is digging in southwestern Poland for a Nazi train said to be filled with stolen gold, gems and art, despite experts’ doubts that the train exists.
item.dc:creator: JOANNA BERENDT

item.title: A Danish Wind Turbine Maker Harnesses Data in a Push to Stay Ahead
item.media:description: Vestas windmills at Provestenen near Copenhagen. The global nature of the industry plays to the strengths of a company like Vestas.
item.media:credit: Laerke Posselt for The New York Times
item.description: Vestas was in a precarious position in 2012, but it is now a market leader, thanks in large part to its focus on data and mathematics.
item.dc:creator: STANLEY REED

item.title: Ernst Neizvestny, a Russian Sculptor Who Clashed With Khrushchev, Dies at 91
item.media:description: Ernst Neizvestny in an undated photograph. He was at odds with the Soviet authorities.
item.media:credit: Fine Art Images/Heritage Images, via Getty Images
item.description: Though his ventures into modernism put him at odds with Soviet cultural authorities in the post-Stalin era, the artist later created a monument for Khrushchev’s grave.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM GRIMES

item.title: Gerald Grosvenor, British Duke and Billionaire, Dies at 64
item.media:description: Gerald Grosvenor at Windsor Castle in 2003.
item.media:credit: Toby Melville/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.description: The sixth Duke of Westminster was the country’s richest landowner, worth an estimated $12 billion, and a friend of the royal family.
item.dc:creator: SAM ROBERTS

item.title: What in the World: Here’s a New Angle on the Shape of the World
item.media:credit: Maziyar Pahlevan
item.description: An Australian statistician has devised a method to rank the world’s nations by how rectangular they are, with Egypt at the head of the class.
item.dc:creator: JAKE DOHERTY

item.title: What in the World: What’s That on Your Bumper? A Hairy Kind of Car Insurance
item.media:credit: Illustration by Alvaro Dominguez; Photos by Bruno Ferrari, Cammep, ArtHeart/Shutterstock
item.description: Ponytails are attached to taxis for strength and good fortune in West Africa. Religious icons are also popular blessings for safe travel.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: When Women Fight ISIS
item.media:description: Kurdish fighters in Tal Hamis, Syria, after it was freed from Islamic State control last year.
item.media:credit: Massoud Mohammed/Barcroft Media, via Getty Images
item.description: Feminists have typically opposed war, but taking up arms is one way for women to defend their communities and to define their place in them.
item.dc:creator: MEREDITH TAX
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: ‘Fractured Lands’: Arab Writers on a Region in Crisis
item.media:description: Near Ben Gardane, Tunisia, March 2011.
item.media:credit: Paolo Pellegrin/Magnum, for The New York Times
item.description: Lessons, regrets and memories, five years after the Arab Spring.
item.dc:creator: SAYED KASHUA, YASMINE EL RASHIDI and KANAN MAKIYA
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: France Has the Burkini Blues
item.media:credit: Fadel Senna/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Banning burkinis is a mistake but French Muslims must demonstrate they accept the core values of secular France.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Brazil Bureau Chief’s Notebook: When the Olympics Media Circus Comes to Town
item.media:description: Residents of the Mangueira neighborhood in Rio de Janeiro watched fireworks during the opening ceremony of the Olympic Games.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: Some of the impressions expressed by journalists parachuting in for the Games call to mind the Onion headline “Woman Who ‘Loves Brazil’ Has Only Seen Four Square Miles of It.”
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Skala Sikaminias Journal: Greek Villagers Rescued Migrants. Now They Are the Ones Suffering.
item.media:description: The keeper of the main church in Skala Sikaminias, Lesbos, looked out to sea. Some villagers say that when they look at the horizon, they often think that another refugee boat is coming.
item.media:credit: Eirini Vourloumis for The New York Times
item.description: The island of Lesbos was ground zero for refugees flooding across the Aegean. A year later, the imprint of that experience still affects one village that tried to help.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Talking to Terrorists
item.media:description: Harry Sarfo, a former Islamic State fighter from Germany, inside the maximum-security prison in Bremen where he is serving a three-year sentence on terrorism charges.
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: For once, the conversation wasn’t via social media, and the name the Islamic State defector used was the one on his birth certificate.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Outstanding Issues: A Yemeni Teenager’s Trip to Estonia, by Way of Guantánamo
item.media:description: Ahmed Abdul Qader, a former Guantánamo Bay detainee, at Freedom Square in Tallinn, Estonia, in May.
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: The reporter Charlie Savage wrote about an ex-Guantánamo inmate’s resettlement; the story didn’t end when the article published.
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: At the Front in a Scarred Falluja
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Bryan Denton, a photographer who works for The New York Times and is based in Beirut, Lebanon, gives his account of covering Iraqi forces’ recapture of Falluja from the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: BRYAN DENTON
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.media:credit: Candace Feit
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT
